div.p:
I did not receive your letter till late yesterday evening
or I should have answerd it sooner. Perhaps often when the post has come in
you have said "Is there no letter for me? No letter from that Miss Edgeworth
She will never write to me! I was very foolish to write to her"
No, I hope this was not what you said or thought [ ] I hope that you
were more patient & that you said She will write to me by & by: I suppose
she has not received my letter" Maybe she lives a great way off
yes she does; do you know how far off? Take a map of Ireland and
put it on the table before you, Now look for the county of Longford. It
is just in the middle of the map, and now look in the midle of the
County. and there you will see printed in little letters
Edgworthtown Edgeworthstown
and that is the place at which I live. You live at Macclesfield as I
see by the date of your letter. I have just looked into the map of England
for Macclesfield and I find that it is in Cheshire so your letter must have
travelled a great way before it reached me. You directed it to St Pauls Church
yard London, first it went from Macclesfield to London that is 171 miles
then from Then from London to Holyhead 300 miles then across the
sea from Holyhead to Ireland which you know is 20 leagues, that is
60 miles, then from Ireland to Edgworths town is sixty miles more
and add them together you will find that they will make 171 300 20 60 60 611 six
hundred & eleven miles! So you must perceive that if all the post men
had galloped as hard as they could and all the horses in all the mail
coaches had been driven as fast as possible if the wind also had blown as
hard as it could blow & as fair to fill the sails of the Ship which carried your
letter to this country yet I could not have received it till several days after
you written wrote & if I had written the moment I had read your
letter yet you could not have received my answer the next day
You can consider & calculate all these things will never be so un-
reasonable unreasonable as some impatient little boys who at the bottom of their
letters write
"I shall expect an answer by return of post
without fail"
even though you wait a few weeks for an answer, it is not agreeable
to be able to tell your thoughts to a person who is at 611 miles distance
I think it is; - for your letter gave me a great deal of pleasure and
I thank you for writing it too; - Your letter not only pleased me
but several of my brothers & sisters and my father & mother & aunts
who were present when I read out it. I received it at supper time
and read it aloud & every body smiled & liked what I read
I read it again at breakfast next morning to some of my brother
& sisters who had been in bed at supper time, & they liked it -
Your "good Mamma" told you very truley that you should
write letters as you would speak to the persons to whom you were
writing; you did so - & therefore your letter was agreable; We all
think you are very fond of your Mother and that she is very kind to
you; - are we mistaken? and we think the brother who took the
trouble of copying your letter, is a very good brother - and that
you must be fond of him too, Are we mistaken? and we think
you are a happy little boy since you have a good mother & a good
brother, and a good friend, Are we mistaken? -

Is your friend Roscoe any relation to the Mr Roscoe who
wrote the life of Lorenzo de Medici which entertain'd us so
much -?

I am glad you had as good a friend as little Dominick
had but I hope you do not find it as difficult as poor little
Dom
inick Dominich
found it to learn the lattin grammar. I can assure you
that it is much more difficult to people to learn it after they
grow old than whilst they are young. (After I had grown up quite
that is as much as ever I could grow (which is very little my
father desired me to try to learn latin because he found several
mistakes in my writings which arose from my not having
been taught grammar well when I was a child; I tried & tried
as much as I cou'd to learn the latin grammar for I always wish'd
to do what my father desired as much as I suppose you wish to do
what your mother desires; but tho I said the verbs & pronouns over
to myself evening & morning and though I wrote them out to make
myself remember them better, yet I found it extreemly difficult to
get them by heart and all the while I saw my little brother William
who was but eight years old learn them with the greatest ease

I am not surprised that you could not understand the essay on
bulls and I am glad that you do not like to read what you do not com
prehend comprehend ; that book was not written for young people and many old people
find it difficult to understand & do not like it.

I am glad the Story of the contrast entertain'd you. We like it the
best of popular tales When I read the note at the end of it, to one
of my brothers before it was printed he said suppose some Body will write
to you" Some body has, and I am glad that I inserted that note - because
it has been the cause of your writing to me. But I must explain the
meaning of that note to you; It was meant to explain ridicule those
who give long descriptions of wedding clothes & fine coats &c as if they thought
such things make people happy. When I was in London about two years
ago I saw hanging up in a mantua makers room, some of the gowns of
a Lady who was to have forty wedding gowns & the Mantua mak
told me that She had lain awake all night & had puzzled herself
to invent different fashions & trimmings for these gowns, one of which
cost 100 gowns guineas. Yet as I was informed by a sensible person the Lady to
whom all these fine things belonged was not likely to be very happy
for she was going to be married to a man who did not love her, & who mar
ried married her only because she was rich. I do not know how many gowns Patty
and Fanny Franklin had I believe they wore white gowns the day
they were married, but whether their husbands wore blue green, brown or red Coats
I cannot tell & I do not think they cared. All I am certain is that they
were very clean, & very likely to be happy because they were good & loved
one another

As to the old father you know that his gray hair was comb'd very smooth
by his father daughter Patty and that his cravat was perfectly clean & white
I dare say that it was washed & iron'd by his daughter Patty who
you know could wash & iron so as to please even Mrs Crump -

I have gone on writing as you did to me, as if I was talking, but
now I must stop for I have heard that Women may talk too much
I had intended to send you a little play which I have just written
but it is fifty pages & that is too much to copy, beside it will
be easier to you to read when it is printed; in the mean time
my father sends you a little book of his writing you will see that it
is French on one side & english on the other & if you are lear
ning learning french it will be very useful to you. I think you will be
entertain'd with the history of Harry & Judy Lucy , tho' they are younger
than you are: this is only the history of a few days of their lives
in two different years: but I hope my father will finish it Some
time or other.
If you like to write to me again, I shall be very glad to hear from
you, but do not write if you do not like it & next time you
need not pay the postage of your letters
div.closer:
Farewell my dear little boy -
Yours affectionately
Maria Edgeworth
Direct to me
Edgeworthstown
Ireland
